subject: Re: Has someone done Servlet JUnit tests?
msgSnippet: ... You can use HTTPUnit to run tests against the servlet.  The problem, however, as you point out, is that you only have limited visibility into the servlet,
messageBody:
Peter Qi wrote:

> I need to create some JUnit tests for a Servlet. But because the
> doGet(HttpServletRequest, HttpServletResponse) and
> doPost(HttpServletRequest, HttpServletResponse) methods have no returns,
> and HttpServletRequest and HttpServletResponse are generated by the
> system, I could not create JUnit tests for them. Does anyone have some
> experience? Thanks a lot for the help.

You can use HTTPUnit to run tests against the servlet. The
problem, however, as you point out, is that you only have
limited visibility into the servlet, since you can only check
the returned HTTP response to the web client. It's gets even
more fun when you're trying to test the behavior of session
time outs, security and log in checks, etc.

What we've discussed doing is to make our servlets (and JSPs
via tag libraries) very thin layers that take the incoming
requests and just delegate to our presentation helper classes.
In many cases, we'll end up just passing the request and
session objects along, but we now have a point where we can
create the request or session objects in particular states
(like expired session), so we can much more easily test the
interface's behavior, plus we can use JUnit.

This isn't a silver bullet or anything, because there are
still cases where you want to test the actual returned HTML,
and sometimes HTTPUnit tests are the best way to do that.
But it seems like it will make our life a bit easier for some
other classes of presentation layer testing.

Anyone else try this?

-Paul Hodgetts
